subject: statistics
title: Wilcoxon Rank-Sum Test: A Step-by-Step Guide
contentHtml: The Wilcoxon rank-sum test is a nonparametric alternative to the two-sample t-test for comparing distributions between two groups.
statementHtml: Suppose we want to compare the distribution of exam scores between students who attended a workshop and those who did not. We have paired data, where each student has an exam score.
hints: Make sure to rank the scores correctly.
The test is sensitive to outliers.
solutionHtml: To perform the Wilcoxon rank-sum test, follow these steps:
answerShort: Reject H0 if W < 0 or W >= W*" },
problemHtml: Suppose we have the following paired data:
steps: [ {"stepNumber": 1, "description": "Rank the scores from lowest to highest.", "mathHtml": "\\[R_1 = 2, R_2 = 3, ..., R_{n+1} = {n+1}\]", "explanation": "This step is crucial for the test."}, {"stepNumber": 2, "description": "Calculate the sum of the ranks for each group.", "mathHtml": "\\[W_0 = \\sum_{i=1}^{m} R_i, W_1 = \\sum_{j=m+1}^{n+m} R_j\\]", "explanation": "This step is used to calculate the test statistic."}, {"stepNumber": 3, "description": "Calculate the critical region.", "mathHtml": "\\[W* = Φ^{-1}(1-α) \\cdot (n+1)\\]", "explanation": "The critical region depends on the significance level and sample size."} ],
finalAnswer: Reject H0 if W < 0 or W >= W*" },
intuition: The Wilcoxon rank-sum test is a powerful tool for comparing distributions between two groups. By ranking the scores, we can identify any differences in the distribution of exam scores.

subject: statistics
title: Wilcoxon Rank-Sum Test
contentHtml: The Wilcoxon rank-sum test is a nonparametric statistical test used to compare two independent groups.

problem.statementHtml: Suppose we want to compare the average ranking of two different treatments for a certain disease. We collect data on the rankings and want to determine if there is a significant difference between the two treatments.
hints: Hint: The Wilcoxon rank-sum test is used when the data are not normally distributed.
problem.solutionHtml:
To solve this problem, we will follow these steps:

  • Rank the data from both groups together, giving each observation a unique ranking.
  • Calculate the sum of the rankings for each group.
  • Compare the sums using the Wilcoxon rank-sum statistic formula.
problem.answerShort: Reject the null hypothesis if T is significant.

workedExample.problemHtml:
Suppose we have two groups of patients, one receiving treatment A and the other receiving treatment B. We collect data on their rankings for a certain symptom:

  • Treatment A: 2, 4, 7, 9
  • Treatment B: 1, 3, 5, 8

steps.description: Rank the data from both groups together
steps.explanation: We rank the data to remove any differences in scales between the two treatments.

steps.description: Calculate the sum of the rankings for each group
steps.explanation: We calculate the sum of the rankings for each group to compare them.

steps.description: Compare the sums using the Wilcoxon rank-sum statistic formula
steps.explanation: We use the Wilcoxon rank-sum statistic formula to compare the sums.

workedExample.finalAnswer: Reject the null hypothesis if T is significant.

intuition: The Wilcoxon rank-sum test helps us determine if there's a difference between two treatments, even when the data aren't normally distributed.

subject: statistics
title: Wilcoxon Rank-Sum Test: A Step-by-Step Guide
contentHtml: The Wilcoxon rank-sum test is a nonparametric alternative to the two-sample t-test for comparing distributions between two groups.
statementHtml:
Suppose we want to compare the distribution of exam scores between students who received A's and those who received B's. We have the following data:
A'sB's
75, 80, 85, 9060, 65, 70, 75, 80, 85
hints: Consider the ranks of the scores rather than their actual values.
The Wilcoxon test is robust to non-normality and outliers.
solutionHtml:
To perform the Wilcoxon rank-sum test:

  1. Combine the two datasets into one.
    2. \[ \]
  2. Rank all the scores from lowest to highest, regardless of group membership.
    3. \[ \]
  3. Calculate the sum of the ranks for each group.
    4. \[ \]
  4. Compare the sums using a two-tailed test statistic and p-value.
",
answerShort: Reject the null hypothesis if the p-value is below a certain significance level." },
problemHtml: Using the data above, perform the Wilcoxon rank-sum test to determine whether there's a significant difference in exam scores between students who received A's and those who received B's.
steps: [ {"stepNumber": 1, "description": "Combine the two datasets", "mathHtml": "", "explanation": "This allows us to compare the distributions directly."}, {"stepNumber": 2, "description": "Rank all the scores", "mathHtml": "\(\text{Ranks: } 1, 2, 3, \ldots, 14\)", "explanation": "We ignore group membership and focus on the relative positions of the scores."}, {"stepNumber": 3, "description": "Calculate the sum of ranks for each group", "mathHtml": "\(\text{A's: } 76 + 83 + \ldots = 341\)", "explanation": "This step is crucial in determining the test statistic."}, {"stepNumber": 4, "description": "Compare the sums using a two-tailed test statistic and p-value", "mathHtml": "", "explanation": "The p-value will indicate whether the difference between the groups is statistically significant."} ],

subject: statistics
title: Wilcoxon Rank-Sum Test: A Step-by-Step Guide
contentHtml: The Wilcoxon rank-sum test is a nonparametric alternative to the t-test that's particularly useful when dealing with ordinal or categorical data.
statementHtml:
Suppose we want to compare the median scores of two groups: students who received treatment A and those who received treatment B. We have the following data:

  • Treatment A: 4, 5, 6, 7, 8
  • Treatment B: 3, 4, 5, 6, 9
hints: Consider the distribution of the scores
solutionHtml: To perform the Wilcoxon rank-sum test, we'll follow these steps:
steps: [ {"stepNumber": 1, "description": "Combine the data into a single list", "mathHtml": "\\[4, 3, 5, 6, 7, 8, 9\\]", "explanation": "This helps us ignore any differences in scales between the two groups"}, {"stepNumber": 2, "description": "Rank the combined data", "mathHtml": "\\[1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7\\]", "explanation": "We're treating this as a single sample, so we can rank all the scores together"}, {"stepNumber": 3, "description": "Calculate the test statistic", "mathHtml": "\\[W = \\sum_{i=1}^n (R_i - \\frac{n+1}{2})\\]", "explanation": "The Wilcoxon rank-sum test statistic is the sum of the differences between each observation's rank and the median rank"}, {"stepNumber": 4, "description": "Determine the p-value", "mathHtml": "\\[p = \\text{Pr}(W \leq w)\\]", "explanation": "We can use a statistical software or calculator to find the p-value for our test statistic"} ],
intuition: The Wilcoxon rank-sum test is useful when we have ordinal or categorical data and want to compare the distribution of scores between two groups.

subject: statistics
title: Wilcoxon Rank-Sum Test: A Step-by-Step Guide
contentHtml: The Wilcoxon rank-sum test is a nonparametric statistical test used to compare two groups based on their ranks.

problem.statementHtml:
Suppose we want to compare the average ranks of two groups: a treatment group and a control group. We have the following data:

  • Treatment Group: 2, 3, 5, 7
  • Control Group: 1, 4, 6, 8
hints: Consider the ranks of the observations
problem.solutionHtml:
To perform the Wilcoxon rank-sum test, we first need to combine the two groups and rank all the observations from lowest to highest:

  • 1. Control Group: 1, 4, 6, 8
  • 2. Treatment Group: 2, 3, 5, 7

workedExample.problemHtml: We will now go through the steps of the Wilcoxon rank-sum test:

steps.description: Combine the two groups and rank all observations
steps.explanation: This helps us to identify any differences between the two groups

steps.description: Calculate the sum of the ranks for each group
steps.explanation: The sum of the ranks for the treatment group is calculated separately from the control group

steps.description: Calculate the expected value of the test statistic
steps.explanation: The expected value of the test statistic is calculated based on the sample sizes and the total number of observations
The test statistic is calculated by subtracting the expected value from the sum of the ranks for the treatment group

intuition: The Wilcoxon rank-sum test helps us to identify any differences between two groups based on their ranks, without making assumptions about the underlying distribution.
